abstract: I think it’s fair to say that some readers reacted negatively to my last post.
snippet: I think it’s fair to say that some readers reacted negatively to my last post.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I wrote a post about the adoption of our core values. I explained that we created awards that honor employees who best demonstrate those values and give us extra incentive to deliver great service. I also explained that I’d asked everyone to rate their team members — on a scale of 1 to 10 — on how well they align with our values, a process that helped me identify a couple of employees who really weren’t a good fit. I think it’s fair to say that some readers reacted negatively to this post.

headline.main: Core Values and Employees Who Don’t Belong, Part 2

abstract: My accountant just does the taxes. But that can’t be the best arrangement, can it?
snippet: My accountant just does the taxes. But that can’t be the best arrangement, can it?
lead_paragraph: No story today, just a question: what is the proper kind of relationship to have with one’s accountant? I see my bookkeeper twice a week, so I know where the money is going, but I’ve never actually met the accountant (she was hired by my ex-partner). As far as I know, there’s nothing wrong with her work. We ship her the ledgers at the end of the year and get back the tax returns in March, and that’s it. That can’t possibly be the best arrangement, but I’m curious as to what the alternatives are. And while I’m at it, a few more queries:

headline.main: What Should I Ask of My Accountant?

lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group agreed to sell its credit card payment processing unit to the Advent International Corporation and Bain Capital for £1.7 billion ($2.7 billion), the companies said Friday. The Royal Bank could receive a further £200 million if the buyers’ returns hit certain targets, the bank said. The Royal Bank will keep a 20 percent stake. The Royal Bank is being forced to dispose of the unit to comply with the European Union’s state-aid rules after taking £45.5 billion ($72 billion) in a rescue packaged financed by taxpayers during the financial crisis.

abstract: Lower tax rates clearly help the poor and the middle class increase their spending. But the same can’t be said for the rich.
snippet: Lower tax rates clearly help the poor and the middle class increase their spending. But the same can’t be said for the rich.
lead_paragraph: A CENTRAL lesson of the Great Depression was that economies mired in deep downturns seldom recover quickly on their own. Consumers won’t spend because they’re worried about losing their jobs  if they haven’t lost them already  and are busy paying down debt. Companies won’t invest because they already have more than enough capacity to satisfy existing demand. That leaves government. It’s the only remaining actor with both the means and the motive to bolster total spending substantially.

abstract: A set of puzzles on stacking items to protrude over the edge — of a table, or a canyon.
snippet: A set of puzzles on stacking items to protrude over the edge — of a table, or a canyon.
lead_paragraph: You are on the Grand Canyon Skywalk, shown above, standing on the glass-bottomed structure that projects out 70 feet over the edge. You look down through the glass below your feet at the sheer fall into the Colorado River 4,000 feet below. Click here, to get a sense of the experience. You know you are safe, but suddenly you are stricken with fear: the perfectly normal feeling of mild acrophobia. It almost overcomes you — that tingling in your feet, that vague dread in the pit of your stomach, that imp in your mind insistently asking “What if I fell?” You brush away the feeling, trusting your rationality, trusting in the safety of physics and engineering. Today we’ll look at over-the-precipice engineering, and then I’m going to do my best to give you some acrophobia again.

headline.main: Numberplay: Hanging Over the Edge

lead_paragraph: My post last week asked, “Did Low Interest Rates Cause the Great Housing Convulsion?” as I discussed my research with Joseph Gyourko and Joshua Gottlieb. It drew a hefty dose of comments from readers, along the lines of, “You idiot, don’t you know it was ridiculous lending with no down payments and no documentation?” Yet it is as hard to make a strong case that high approval rates and high loan-to-value ratios caused the boom as it is easy to opine that they obviously did.

The article focuses on a decision made by Richard S. Braddock, FreshDirect’s chief executive, in early 2008. Mr. Braddock decided that his company’s customer service was so poor that it had to stop soliciting new customers — its biggest source of revenue — until it figured out how to serve them. The risk, of course, was that the company would run out of money before it solved its problems.

abstract: Fund managers should occasionally say no to new cash to keep from hurting performance. But in the money business, that’s easier said than done.

lead_paragraph: It stands to reason that the more money flowing to a particular investment strategy, the more likely returns will diminish. By logical extension, fund managers should therefore occasionally say no to new cash to keep from hurting performance. But in the money business, that’s easier said than done, especially when considering the growing number of alternative asset managers that are publicly traded.

abstract: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast: Brian Stelter on the Google-Verizon net neutrality plan and Miguel Helft on the BlackBerry brouhaha.

lead_paragraph: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast,  Brian Stelter, a Times media reporter, drops by to chat about Internet access regulation with J.D. Biersdorfer and Bettina Edelstein. The so-called net neutrality plan of Google and Verizon would exempt wireless and some other online services from rules for maintaining open access to the Internet, and Mr. Stelter says that while the two companies  appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating broadband.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Net Neutrality

abstract: Being responsible for your workers’ jobs is hard. Being responsible for their careers is harder.
snippet: Being responsible for your workers’ jobs is hard. Being responsible for their careers is harder.
lead_paragraph: As sales pick up, I’ve been trying to build our production capacity proportionally. This has been hard for me to accomplish in the past. During the last big expansion, between 2003 and 2008, I found myself in the position of hiring willy-nilly, throwing warm bodies at production bottlenecks. In the rush to get work out the door, we never set up a training program and we didn’t do a good job of increasing productivity with technology. This was a disastrous mistake. More than anything else, an inflated payroll drained cash from the company and kept us from making a profit.

headline.main: Do I Owe My Employees a Career Path?

Three minutes and 18 nigiri later, time is up, and his instructor comes around to sort the well-shaped ones from the ill-shaped, as Mr. Aoki wistfully looks on. Just 12 have made the grade.

abstract: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations.
snippet: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations.
lead_paragraph: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations and that recordings should be excluded from his insider trading trial. The ruling was made by Judge Richard J. Holwell of United States District Court in Manhattan in an opinion released Friday. Prosecutors said the government secretly recorded about 2,400 conversations that the hedge fund executive had with more than 130 friends, business associates and supposed accomplices. Mr. Rajaratnam is the central figure in two overlapping prosecutions in which 21 people have been charged. He was accused of earning millions of dollars from stock trades made with inside information from corporate officials and hedge fund executives. He has denied wrongdoing.

headline.main: Galleon Founder Wins a New Hearing Over Wiretaps

abstract: In other rich countries, the unemployment rate is much higher for immigrants than for the native-born. In the United States, the two rates are roughly equal.

lead_paragraph: A few months back, we observed that last year, and for the first time since 2003, foreign-born workers were more likely to be unemployed than their counterparts born in the United States. The unemployment rate was only slightly higher for immigrants to the United States than for American natives, however; immigrants in other industrialized countries did not fare so well.

The headstone is engraved with two roosters facing off, their feathers ruffled. Kenneth, who loved cockfighting, died in 1999, and, Ms. Scarbro says, he would have hated seeing the tops of mountains lopped off with explosives and heavy machinery by mining companies searching for coal.

abstract: A set of simple problems to show the fickleness of estimating probabilities and the subtlety required to get them right.
snippet: A set of simple problems to show the fickleness of estimating probabilities and the subtlety required to get them right.
lead_paragraph: The determination of probabilities is a well-established branch of mathematics. Very often probability calculations are simple and yield exact values that seem absolute and objective. Not so! Today I give you three scenarios with questions whose calculations are mostly simple. They are meant to show two things: first, that probability is relative – the probability of something may be very different depending on the way it is measured; and second, that probability is a measure of our ignorance. Any piece of knowledge, no matter how seemingly irrelevant, can change the probability for us.

headline.main: Numberplay: The Relativity of Probability

abstract: Shares of Intuit, the provider of personal finance software, rose the most in 18 months in Nasdaq composite trading after its annual forecast topped estimates and the company announced plans for a $2 billion stock buyback.
snippet: Shares of Intuit, the provider of personal finance software, rose the most in 18 months in Nasdaq composite trading after its annual forecast topped estimates and the company announced plans for a $2 billion stock buyback.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Intuit, the provider of personal finance software, rose the most in 18 months in Nasdaq composite trading after its annual forecast topped estimates and the company announced plans for a $2 billion stock buyback. Sales will increase at least 8 percent, to $3.74 billion, in the next fiscal year, which ends July 31, 2011, the company said. Excluding some costs, earnings will rise at least 12 percent, to $2.36 a share. Analysts had estimated revenue of $3.72 billion and profit of $2.30 a share on average. Intuit is adding Internet features and using acquisitions to offer more online services. The recently purchased Mint personal finance site increased its customers to more than three million last quarter. Shares in Intuit rose $5.83, or 15 percent, to $44.60.

headline.main: Intuit Forecast Tops Estimates, and Its Shares Rise

Strine Jr. is not going to enjoin the deal. He is also unlikely to touch the termination fee or the matching rights that Hertz has negotiated in its agreement. BHP’s impressive annual results on Wednesday are a reminder of the financial firepower behind its $39 billion hostile bid for Potash, the world’s largest fertilizer group. But they also show that BHP is not broken — and that its chief executive, Marius Kloppers, does not need to bet a strong balance sheet on further diversification.

headline.main: BHP Doing Fine Without Potash
headline.print_headline:
BHP Doing Fine
Without Potash

abstract: Mr. Rowland’s invention, which was an alternative to the folding chair, made it possible to store many chairs in a small space.

lead_paragraph: David Rowland, the industrial designer who made it possible for millions of people to sit in church basements, meeting halls, cultural centers and even submarines in comfortable, sculptured chairs, then to clear the space by stacking them in a corner, died on Aug. 13 at his home in Marion, Va. He was 86.

abstract: With all the focus on the estate tax, many people have not noticed that the gift tax, which this year stands at 35 percent, is at the lowest rate since the 1930s.

lead_paragraph: THE estate tax is a great wedge issue in a politically polarized time. Take this oft-cited example: If a billionaire dies this year, no estate tax will be paid, but the estate of someone with more than $1 million who dies next year will pay a 55 percent tax on that extra amount. That seems arbitrary if not bizarre, but such is the tax regime unless Congress changes it.

headline.main: A Year to Give to Your Heirs, and Save on Taxes
